replies.text:
If you worked for HTC, in their product development department, and your boss asked you what changes need to be made to improve sales, would you tell him/her "let's not make this an indictment on HTC"?
This isn't an HTC only issue, I get that. I've owned 3 HTC phones, and I get that a lot of people go out if their way to kick HTC when they're down. It's usually the same people that have never actually owned a single one of their devices, but formed an opinion after reading a few articles online.
I can't act like nothing is wrong though, and deflecting their issues isn't gonna help anyone. If somebody else wants to create a post about how Android in general, or LG, or whoever else is struggling, that's fine. They can take the time and energy to start their own thread somewhere else.
I want to see them turn it around. It's been an extraordinary fall from grace given where they were just a short time ago. I want to see the M10 have an M7 like impact amongst Android fans. Hopefully whatever changes they're making will result in a better phone and a better company, cause they simply can't survive at this rate much longer.
I think the best thing that can happen would be if an Asus or some other company bought them and infused the cash they so desperately need. 
You're dead on with the VR, though I remain somewhat skeptical about them trying to generate revenue away from their core business. I'm not the best person to ask though cause I simply don't get VR and the interest behind it. It's in the same category as 3D TVs and Google Glass, but like I said, I'm simply not a fan. But I do recognize from a business perspective that it's probably necessary and it's that type of innovation and forward thinking that they'll need to be successful moving forward. 
Always best to be proactive instead of reactive in the tech business. There's also nothing wrong with not trying to reinvent the wheel, so hopefully they'll find a balance between the two and get back to doing what they do best.

VR isn't 3d TV's. Yes. Those were a gimmick waste of time. HTC VR has Gaming and educational applications that are way ahead of what the competition is doing and with stunning detail and realism. I no longer even want a home theater room in my basement. I am going to set up a VR room. I am an early adopter by nature but I don't waste time with things like 3D TV's that have little potential or head room for growth and applications. VR is the future. HTC is smart to diversify into it and their product has that potential. I just hope they get first mover advantage and can stick around long enough to see the other side when it becomes more mainstream.
Posted via the Android Central App

I'm sorry, I should've done a better job clarifying. To me, it's in the same category as 3D TV, though I clearly recognize for the general public it's not. I'm just not into the whole VR thing, but definitely understand there's a major market for it.

Samsung has $100B in cash on hand and, while down, the Mobile Division is still contributing multi-billion dollar quarterly profits. Samsung the full company made more revenue and profit in Q2 2015 than 2014. Their move to their own chips, memory, and camera sensors is helping drive profit outside the mobile division. They are a big diversified company and no matter what the changing smartphone market brings you'd expect them to continue to dominate it, even at a lower margin, once they regain their stride. 
As for HTC they're a one trick pony and have basically burned up the clock. In 2012 they said they had too many phones and were going to focus on the high end. They don't have the scale, financial resources for marketing, and broad distribution Samsung and Apple do so fell on their face. The next strategy was to own the premium low cost segment in emerging markets. Their cost base vs. the Chinese and Indians caused that to tank. Now they are going back to fewer premium phones again. Cher and Peter killed HTC and if it were a Western company both would have been removed by shareholders years ago. Do you know how long it's going to take for things like wearables and VR to reach critical mass and profitability? Chasing emerging products when you can't pay today's bills is a fool's journey. Stick a fork in HTC, they're done.

thread.text:
The Barrage of Bad Publicity
I think the M9 was hurt more by the state it was in when initially shipped and reviewed than anything else. HTC needed the word on the street to be that the phone had an exceptional camera, that didn't happen. The screen is now more accurate than the M8's but was labelled dull.
Meanwhile, there's hardly any marketing of the phone as the audiophile's choice.
It feels like all the departments just need to work in sync better.

Part of me says that they can make the M10 or whatever it'll be called, the best device in the history of smartphones and it still would do little to help their profits.
The other side of me thinks that reviving the EVO brand with distribution across all carriers in the respective market, would be something I'd like to see them do. I'm still convinced that specs don't make a phone a sales success in today's market, but the image, and appeal (based on several factors i.e., value, design, etc) of the device. With that said, focusing on imaging and audio prowess and marketing those strengths appropriately will be the best chance for them I think.
Posted via the Android Central App

The issue is that they have so many phones under that "One" branding.
In the West, we only have the M9 (minus the M9+ in Europe) and that's basically their flagship, but look in Asia and see how many phones are in the "One" series. Here are a couple.HTC One M9+HTC One MEHTC One E9+HTC One M8sHTC Butterfly 2HTC One E9
There's more and there's also the Desire line, where there's even more.
There's more phones in that lineup than the Galaxy S line, Galaxy Note line, LG G line and XPERIA Z line had in a year.
Just make one 5-inch flagship under the "One" brand and release a larger one for those that want a bigger size. Make the Desire solely for midrangers and have another name for a budget-oriented line.
Take Motorola for instance. This is their product line.
Moto X series - Flagship (Style), Upper-midrange (Play)
Moto G series - Midrange
Moto E series - Economy/Budget

replies.text: nailed it ... like others have stated, it might not even matter what they do at this point, but in terms of the amount of models, I totally agree with have a 5" (or thereabouts) and phablet under the One brand, then similar to Moto have a midrange, and maybe even an economy brand ... keep it simple, and keep it consistent.

title: Volume turning itself down and unable to turn off phone sometimes?

thread.text:
I shut down my phone for a couple hours and turned it back on. Then I watched YouTube and listened to music for another couple hours. Suddenly, the volume just started turning itself all the way down randomly? It's never done this before and it's a brand new phone (HTC One M9). I'd like to know how to fix this ASAP because I use my phone for music and videos a lot. I am not accidentally hitting the volume buttons because for music, I often do not hold my phone at all. 
Another problem is that I sometimes cant turn off my phone using the power button. The only way it turns off is the auto screen shut down. I can turn it on afterwards, but again, not off.

Sounds like you have an odd bug in the software. 
I say software because the physical button used for the power is the same if your using it to turn the device on or off. If it works fine to turn it ON, but giving you issues to turn it OFF, then it sort of rules out hardware. 
You may want to consider resetting your device and going from there.
Could be worse. My DNA would randomly turn the volume all the way up... almost blew my ear drums out a few times when I had headphones on.

thread.text:

I have this issue though and I'm not sure if it's a big issue or if it's common. Sometimes when I press the power button the screen doesn't wake up until I press the power button a second time. Almost as if it didn't recognize the first press and did the second. It's only happened about 2-3 times in the last 2 days I've had it. I don't know if it's that I am not pushing the button hard enough or if this is a common issue? I thought I had seen something about this somewhere else but I can't find that post/article anymore. replies.text: Are you using it with or without a case? The only time I've had that happen is with a cheapo case from Amazon that didn't seem to fit like it should.

thread.text: I'd get it replaced - it sounds like either a flakey switch or something stuck between the button and the switch, or the case and the button, making it not work all the time. (I did that with an LG G2 by swapping 2 buttons that looked the same - but the power button stopped working until I swapped them back.) It's always possible that, no matter how clean they keep the factory, some dirt got into the phone, causing a problem.

I've had the same issue a few times as well. In my case it wasn't so much an issue with the power button, but I attributed it to a software issue that was causing significant latency between the time that the power button was pressed and the time the display activated. I'm not sure which software applications you're running or what you're display configuration is, but that might be something to consider.
Posted via the Android Central App

Go into Go to Settings > Display & gestures > Motion Launch gestures. Make sure the feature is enabled. If the problem is still there take a look at this post about what to do to troubleshoot issues that may be occurring after an update: Android 5.0 Lollipop bugs got you down? title: Photos often only show the top half of the picture. Why?

thread.text: Teenage daughter has an M9 and the camera occasionally takes a picture and when saved, only the top half of the photo is shown and saved. Sometimes the lower portion, which can vary from 50-80% of the original photo is white; other times it is gray. Sometimes the lower half of the photo is a ghost from another photo. Any ideas how to fix this? She has not upgraded the camera software yet.

replies.text: Are photos being saved to gallery or micro sd?
I believe microSD.

thread.text:
I would try removing the micro SD, rebooting, and try using the phone's storage to make sure there's not something wrong with the card.
Sent from my HTC One M9 using Tapatalk

replies.text: Will have her try that.

thread.text: Removed SD card. Still happens with phone storage. Maybe the camera chip is bad. May need to exchange. Seems half of the photos are affected.

Is it always this way, or hit and miss? The reason I ask is because it seems odd that the sensor would be bad in some way that would allow it to occasionally be the top and then be the bottom, also it would never have a portion of another pic... It sounds like a storage or resource issue. Is this the stock app? Have you tried a third party app from the PS? Does it still occur after a restart? Is a power saver or memory saver app being ran on the device? Or anti virus? Disable any of those apps, restart the device and try again. Get a third party app.
Posted via the Android Central App from my HTC One M9

replies.text: Stock Sprint M9. No third party apps. No power saver running, and not the one Sprint puts on there. Happens 60% of the time. Some photos that initially look great end up cut off or have gray or white sections inserted. I will try deleting the camera app and reinstalling from the Play store.
At this point I'd probably take it in for an exchange. That would definitely be considered a defect, so there shouldn't be any problems. Or you could have her try a factory reset.

thread.text: I really want to know.

Looks like the SDcard was the problem. Just too slow for some reason. Without it, the camera saves the entire picture. I think it is some offbeat brand. Checks out ok, and stores files and things just fine on any computer, but seems to bee too slow for the M9. Fortunately, she is back from her 3 week trip to Russia and she took multiple pics of the same thing, and usually 60% of the time the pics were fine.

replies.text: Glad you found the culprit! By chance, do you know what camera mode she has been using? When using RAW, and sometimes HDR my card takes forever to process the image. If I move the phone too fast I get bad pics. In auto or manual I don't have the problem. I was just curious.

thread.text:
What class is the SD card? It might be too slow for the phone. The 10 in the circle is the class. That's how many mb/s can be wrote to the card. Lower number, slower speed which can also be a reason for your problem.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: Your favorite car mounts for M9? Anyone use a magnetic one without going into dot view?

thread.text:
I'm trying to figure out how to mount my M9 in my '09 Santa Fe. Ideally:Sits next to the wheel on the right hand sideFits my phone with a very thin case on it (I don't like clunky cases so much)Charges the phone (at the very least allows for easy charging)Mounts on the dash, not the windshield
I realize that there is also a reality that some people choose to live in.
I would be fine with a magnetic holder, but it doesn't seem to take a lot of magnetism to activate the dot matrix mode. Anyone have successes with this?

I dug around in Settings to disable dot view, and my magnetic mount no longer is a problem.
UPDATE:
Settings > Personalize > (scroll down a bit) HTC Dot View, tap on that, and it shows Dot View Themes. Tap on the "hamburger" icon next to Themes > Settings > uncheck Turn on HTC Dot View
Sent from my HTC One M9 on Tapatalk

Oh ****! I had seen online that people were trying to root their phones to do this. Maybe they were trying to uninstall or use the magnet for something else (like car mode). Any reviews on magnetic mounts then?

Kenu Airframe. Regular size. Low profile, great materials, $30. Fits in the vent in a variety of different positions including landscape if you need it, and it's easy to remove and doesn't look ugly when the phone isn't on. Highly recommended!
Posted via the Android Central App

Looks slick, for sure. Still, I'd like to keep my vents free if possible, looking for a proper dash mount. Also, probably going to be using a Spigen Neo Hybrid Series Case. 
Looked at Steelies, I don't think I would have a problem with cutting a hole in the case to make it sit flush, but I don't like the idea of having anything mounted on the outside of the case. It would also be nice to be able to stick my phone to things, I use my hands a lot. Have heard about destroying credit cards with those though. And if they stick out too far from the case, they'll make your phone spin while laying flat (once again, I use my hands a lot).
Opinions on the iMagnet? Realistically, I have magnets. With the little backing plate I could still stick my phone to other things. If it would hold, I might be interested. Does their "patented suction cup" actually work well? What about when it's 100 degrees out?

replies.text: The good thing about the vent mounted ones though is that your phone stays cooler while using GPS. The M9 gets a little toasty from it sometimes.

Not if you have the heat on in the winter. . Bends the vents and prone to breaking them. 
Via my HTC One M9...

I have used a Kenu for more than 2 years now. In the winter I just turn off the vent to keep the heat off of the phone. In the summer I leave the A/C blowing thru the vent. Vent slats have not bent at all. Wife has one, too. Works for iPhone and Android. I have had the regular Kenu and the Kenu+. Get the Kenu Airframe+. Gives you more flexibility for cases. Great for traveling. Lightweight. Can stick a hotel room key/card in the slot and the Kenu becomes a viewing stand for videos.

^^^ all of this. I've tried dash, vent, and lighter mounts and the kenu comes out on top.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text: I've used one by Tetrax for years and never had an issue with the magnet. Very low profile and works great. There are a few different models but this is the one I bought: [apparently don't have enough posts to include links but it's the Tetrax 72008 at Amazon]

I have used this previously for travel..works well in any car.http://www.aliexpress.com/item/2014-...218642464.html
2015 New Black Car Dashboard Sticky Pad Mat Anti Non Slip Gadget Mobile Phone GPS Holder Interior Items Accessories-in Holders & Stands from Phones & Telecommunications on Aliexpress.com | Alibaba Group[/url] $1.39
This little mount is meant to stick on your dash with included 3m pads. I just couldn’t make myself do that on my dash..but I am using this on my office desk, and the little metal disk was the thinnest and smallest attachable magnetic piece so I am using that (turned around so the silver side shows and pretty closely matches the color of my m9 back) with the larger vent magnet below. $3.59http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Best-...312638436.html
Finally…this is what I am currently using, with the metal disk from above. I put mine in the side window vent..further up the dash from the regular AC vent and to the left of my steering. This allows the cord to be unobtrusive and unseen by a passenger. I ran a power outlet under seat and under carpet mat. The USB connector comes out under dash space near the steering wheel.Auto Car Holder Mini Air Vent Outlet Mount Magnet Magnetic Phone Mobile Holder-in Holders & Stands from Phones & Telecommunications on Aliexpress.com | Alibaba Group $2.30.
****AS someone else noted in another thread..the vent mount units have two different "tightness" fingers..rotate the mount and try both. The smaller/tighter ones work best for me*** 
So...you can try them all for under $15...just have to be willing to wait a little longer than Amazon or Ebay.

I think I'm going to go with the iClever, based on reviews from amazon. These are cheap, so its not a crime against humanity if I end up buying two. Maybe my girlfriend just has a gift coming... Thanks everyone for your help, if the magnetic ones don't work, for whatever reason, I'll try the kenu.

title: Stuck in recovery loop after failed 5.1 update (HTC One M9), how can I make it?

thread.text:
Hello –
I have an HTC One M9 (AT&T) which is stock and unrooted. Apparently a failed 5.1 update while traveling abroad has caused my phone to get stuck in recovery mode. Rebooting the phone or powering down simply brings the phone back to recovery. I am hoping there might be a way to update a stock ROM or force an OTA update without losing any of the internal data on the phone. Alternatively I was hoping I could pull the photos from the phone before wiping or returning the phone.
My only options on this screen are to:
reboot system now; apply update from ADB; wipe data/factory reset; wipe cache partition; reboot to bootloader; power down; view recovery logs; apply from phone storage; apply from sd card
I have tried all options multiple times, but I have not tried a factory reset because all of my pictures from my trip are still on the internal memory of the phone.
Unfortunately I never enabled USB debugging before the device failure, so I believe my options with ADB and “pulling” the files are limited. Nonetheless, my phone won’t communicate effectively with my PC or laptop while in recovery mode, my PC and laptop only recognize that an Android device is connected while in bootloader or download mode.
I have been told by HTC that my only option is to download and update the ROM that is available on their website to the phone, but this will erase all data on my phone.
Is there any other possible option for me that can kick my phone out of recovery mode, or extract the photos from the internal storage? Is there a different ROM or OTA update I can use that will retain my data once installed?
Thanks!

replies.text: I had that same problem and was able to get out of it with the help of the online support. They basically told me to reboot the system now. Then I had to do a google checkin. Do you have your old phone? I think the best option is to back up to your old phone using a file transfer, and then doing the factory reset. The only way I get all my photos and data back the way I wanted it was through the transfer of info using my One x+. I'd recommend the google checkin first, as I did both before being able to get the update to work. Doing a back up using the Sync Manager took too much time and was extremely annoying.

title: 5.1 Update issue (AT&T), any fix?

thread.text: So, I see that there are a handful of us having the issue with the update not loading (aborting). Anyone have any new info or a fix? Not rooted, never modified anything, pretty generic user, can't understand why this happens.

Yes. After many hours and headaches, I was able to update it. I did a factory reset, and I did a Google check with the help of HTC Online chat support. I would recommend trying online chat support for resetting the Google check in before doing a factory reset, as I'm now dealing with how to get my photos back into my gallery from Google photos, where they are backed up.
Posted via the Android Central App

Just tried my third OTA update without success. I was avoiding the manual update because I didn't want to have it wipe my phone, but if a factory reset is the only other option to get the OTA to work, I might as well go manual.

Go to HTC Online chat support. See if they can walk you through a Google check in. If that helps, you won't have to do the factory reset or manual update.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: What is a "Google check in"? I just tried searching Google for that, and didn't find anything useful. Can you please provide some more info?

Here is what "Danielle" told me in HTC Chat support:"We'll try to get the update to pull through by doing what's called a Google Checkin. This essentially resets your device's connection to the Google and update servers. To do this, open your dial pad as though you were going to make a phone call, then enter *#*#2432546#*#*. After this you should see a "Google Checkin Complete" in your notification bar at the top."

thread.text:
I don't really know what it is. The person I spoke to told me to dial a number that consisted of asterisks and pound signs in front of several random numbers. As soon as I dialed, it said the check in was complete. That was it. Like I said, you would have to ask HTC support.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: My stock M9 is stuck in bootloop! Can't boot to recovery! Help please!

thread.text:
Hello guys!
First and foremost, I'm new to the forum as well as an Android noob (switched from Iphone 5 half a year ago). I have never rooted my phone nor have I flashed a custom ROM before. I have a 32 GB HTC One M9 from Verizon on stock Lollipop Android, and it has been working perfectly until this morning. I woke up to my M9 stuck in a bootloop. It would boot to the HTC logo, stay there for about 10 sec, then go black and constantly restart again (even as I type this). I can access the bootloader, but it seems none of the options work for me! I can't boot to recovery mode or even power off my phone. It just constantly boots again by itself. I've emailed HTC support and hope to hear from them soon, but I figured why not ask ask a respected forum as well. I've read up on similar issues from other people, but it seems none of their solutions work for me as I cannot access recovery or even do a hard reset! Any help is appreciated! I want to be able to use my phone ASAP!
- John

Can u get on a computer and go to HTC support online chat? They are super helpful. I learned through them that if you push on the power button and volume up, it reboots the phone. Then as soon as it hits the black screen, if you push volume down, it will go to a screen that will allow you to clear the cache and start up again. But do the online chat support.
Posted via the Android Central App

I have tried it but I waited for half an hour with no response, so I decided to email them instead. Will try online chat again later though. The problem is, I can't clear the cache because I can't boot to recovery :c

An update for all those who might have the same problem. I've successfully contacted HTC live chat support and have found out that my device is defective. I have no idea what the cause might be, or if there is even a solution to fix it yourself. I will be receiving a replacement device in two days thanks to HTC's wonderful customer support and exchange program. Thanks to all who provided input!

It's a Priority Interruptions icon. To get it outta there go to:

title: MTP File Transfers

thread.text: I know how transfer files from Windows 7 laptop to HTC via MTP. It is really fast, even though where files end up on my HTC can be a mystery.How do I send files from HTC to laptop? I don't see anything MTP-related in SHARE on my HTC and end up using Bluetooth which is very slow. !!! THANKS !!!

replies.text: I usually use AirDroid to transfer stuff from my phone to my laptop. It's pretty quick and works over wifi so you don't have to connect the phone.

thread.text:
RESOLVED: I am embarrassed at how easy HTC-to-laptop transfers are via USB. With cable attached + MTP enabled, just click or double click:
"My Computer" on laptop
"HTC One M9" under "Portable Devices"
"Internal storage" or "SD card"
select files or folders to be transferred
"EDIT" from menu bar at top of screen
"Copy to folder" -or- "Move to folder"
A window will open, and just select where files from HTC should be transferred to on laptop.
Lots of steps, but I have lousy wireless connectivity and prefer USB.
Since the HTC screen is so small, I also like accessing HTC files from my laptop with MS Office, Acrobat or other laptop application and view / edit / print (not perfectly but good enough). I am not a fan of MS Office Android apps.
This is my first and probably last smartphone ... and it has become my "pocket" laptop, my favorite toy!
Posted via the Android Central App

title: Google - Time to Home

thread.text: How do I get Google to quit popping up all day long telling me how long it will take to get home and how the traffic is???

If you don't use that feature, you can completely disable Location History in your Google settings (this will save a considerable amount of battery). But if you do use that feature, just don't want to have the notifications, whenever you see it, just tap on it (or if you open Google and you see the card, that works too). Now tap on the three dots on top of the notification. It will give you two sections, one to modify your means of transportation and another to stop receiving travel time notifications altogether. 
Remember, that feature 'learns' from you, so it tries to provide that information around the time you usually go home or whenever you're away from home and not at work. For me it's quite useful, but many find it annoying hehe.

title: Verizon M9 Missing Manual Controls in RAW?

thread.text:
I'm on Verizon and after receiving the update through the Play Store that enabled RAW, I'm missing the little bar with the manual controls while in RAW. Even the new update this morning did not have it. 
There's a thread on XDA in the Verizon M9 section, so as far as I can tell, it seems only Verizon M9s are affected, but I'm trying to confirm this. I called HTC yesterday and reported it finally. Of course, their only solution is to try a factory reset, but I don't think that will fix it. I've tried everything else I can think of tho. 
Anyone else have this issue and what carrier?

I don't think I have this on my T-mobile version either
Posted via the Android Central App

No manual settings in RAW mode on my t-mobile.
The main point of shooting in raw, is that the image contains a 1:1 of what the sensor sees. There is ZERO work done by the camera software, aside from taking that data and saving it to the phone. Using RAW will let you do much more with the pictures in a program like Adobe Lightroom, Corel Aftershot Pro, or other photography editing tool.
The reason you'll have "manual" controls in normal mode, is that you're telling the camera software what to do with the raw sensor data BEFORE it saves it to the phone. RAW lets you work with the raw sensor data AFTER it's captured.
Think of RAW as photography negatives (actually the DNF format created stands for Digital Negative Format), and normal settings as the developed pictures you'd get after.

replies.text:
There is one caveat to that feature on the M9. Since there isn't a lens profile available, you'll have to do quite a bit of guessing to correct the distortion and vignetting that the lens produces (which is quite bad in my opinion) when working with the RAW files in a photo editor application.
Posted via the Android Central App

I understand where you're coming from, but don't think the blanket statement is true. As you say, it's about what's hitting the sensor. If the current settings save a completely blown out image or the exposure length at night is too short to record any light, RAW won't be able to provide anything.

title: Shocking battery drain on M9 - even in airplane mode

I turned off notifications for all apps, including really active ones like Facebook and Instagram. I keep GPS off unless I need it. No Bluetooth, nothing. And yet my battery just drains and drains. 
Last Sunday I kept my phone on airplane mode for most of the day (I did turn the mode off a few times to check texts but then turned back on again). My battery kept draining throughout the day, I started the day at 100%, and by 6pm it was at 20% battery. ON AIRPLANE MODE! 
I can't upload a screenshot right now but battery usage stats say Google Services used 38% of my battery during the day - what is this?! I turn off most things so that Google can't use my phone or notify me of anything, and yet it uses my battery so badly. 
It's making me hate my phone - my old Nexus 5 and then OnePlus One was never this bad. I'm actually jealous of my iPhone friends who can use their phone for a day and a half before charge runs out!! Help please!

replies.text: Install GSAM. Charge your battery full. Drain it to 1-2% left. Screenshot it and post it here. Then we can all get somewhere....

The HTC One M9 will launch with Advanced Calling1.0 capabilities. You can enjoy HD Voice and Video Calling to other compatible Verizon smartphones. Activating this feature also enables simultaneous voice and data use, so customers can talk and surf the web at the same time.

title: Custom Ringtones Disappeared

thread.text: I had custom sounds for my Ringtone and Notifications and over the weekend they just disappeared. The files are still saved in the same directories, but when I go into Setting to change the sound, my custom sounds do not appear any more. Has any one else encountered this? How do I fix this?
Are the custom ringtones saved to Internal Storage or the microSD card? If they're on the card, make sure you put them on Internal Storage (in the Ringtones or Notifications directory).
They are saved to the Internal Storage.
What happens after a reboot, or if you delete the ringtones and then copy them back to the directory again?
I tried several reboots to no avail. I have not deleted the files, but have moved them to different folders and then back, but that does not work either.

replies.text: i put a folder on the sdcard named Music and put them in there. When going into Sound & Notifications/Ringtone tap the + sign then Music

thread.text: I created a "Music" and a "Notifications" folder on the root of my SD Card, copied the files there and now they are showing up.
I also made a folder "Ringtones" on the SD Card and they show up from there as well.
Great! What directory were they saved to before?
Ringtones & Notifications on the Internal Storage
That's pretty weird. Usually, the problem arises when the sound files are stored on the SD card, rather than Internal Storage.

title: Bye Bye M9

thread.text:
Sorry HTC but I have to say bye to the M9.To me the M9 is still the most beautiful device to launch to date but they failed on so many fronts with this iteration. These are the most prominent issues that led me to return:
Excessive heat - Not saying the m8 doesn't get warm but my experience with the m9 was poor. The m9 would constantly top 102 degrees especially when using the camera.
Poor lowlight camera - This has been said many times, but i'll say this again. The lowlight performance of the camera is HORRIBLE!! ( Even after recommended adjustments from XDA)
Poor Battery - The battery drain is significant. GSM Battery continued to give an average of 3.5 hours of screen on which is not up to standards.
Battery while taking pictures - I would literally drop 3 percent in battery life with just 8 pictures taken in a row and even more drain when in low light. Seems like the processor goes into overdrive when the camera is launched thus causing rapid battery drain.
Everything else about the device was beautiful. Design, Screen and UI was boss. 
In the end I think im going to hold off on the newest flagships of 2015 and wait to see what others are offering. I owned an edge as well and didn't see a 800 dollar reason to keep it.
I know there's going to be plenty of the "my M9 doesn't do that crew" but these findings are facts and simply can't be disputed. I love HTC phones but this year's iteration is just not good.

replies.text: I am just curious if you noticed any differences after the U.S. software update in terms of picture quality and heat, which the update was supposed to address?

The update didn't significantly improve the camera performance in lowlight situations. The heat issue was improved, however, it was still very noticeable. The snapdragon 810 seems to be a dud processor. HTC and LG should demand some type of compensation due to poor performance.

I second this, I just returned my M9 today and will be waiting for my 128 gb s6 to arrive. I have had stuttering in the browser(both chrome and internet), loss of gps, excessive heat and poor battery life. Now I will see if the s6 will be up to par, but that remains to be seen.

Good luck. poor battery life is a 64-bit/lollipop issue
I have yet to find a decent Android browser. They all suck.
Well if the s6 fails for me, then I will be returning back to my lumia 1520.

Ha! Go over to the S6 forum. Battery drain is even worse, it lags and stutters too. 
It seems 2015 has began with a step backwards. These two flagships suck. Battery has gone backwards in particular. I look forward to the Z4.
Right this minute, the M8 seems the best overall package and a bargain.

I will reserve judgement for the s6 once I use it. A pity as I was really looking forward toward 64 bit android flagshapes, but it seems like they are simply failing this year. Will probably just be returning to my lumia 1520 it seems.

The Z4 appears to have the same 810 processor, which is not exactly garnering glowing reviews (unless you consider the heat it gives off "glowing"). I'm curious to see how Samsung, HTC, and Google address the complaints of the early adopters to these flagship phones. I'm also curious to see how the LG G4 stacks up. So far, the early press looks impressive.

There was this 90's group called Kriss Kross. They wore all their clothes backwards which made no sense to me then and now. That's how I feel about companies insisting on putting their speakers on the back of the device. Doesn't matter how impressive everything else could be.
Speakers on the back make me wanna jump, jump... Volume buttons on the back make me wanna jump, jump...
As always, the importance of any and all features on a smart phone are completely about user preference. Personally, I find speakers on a cell phone about as useful as Kriss Kross references. ;-)
Thanks for giving me a personal opinion denouncing my personal opinion. How clever...
All I said was, we each place value on different features. You value speakers, I don't. How is that "denouncing your personal opinion"?

I was only talking about having speakers on the back being silly at this point. No one can convince me that is more practical or useful than having front facing ones. Now if you want to summarily dismiss it because you don't care about speakers then that's fair. I actually wouldn't mind the buttons on the back. That leather back looks awful tacky though but that can be changed. Not a fan of their software either. The SOC in the G3 couldn't keep up with the QHD screen and I have my reservations if they use the S810 which I don't think they are. The whole design is a meh to me and the G3 felt cheap in the hand. The camera looks promising though. The screen wasn't as bright so they could improve that as I found it a bit washed out. 
Overall, the only thing I would probably enjoy more on the LG than the HTC experience wise would probably be the camera.

I completely agree with you; putting speakers on the back is a poor choice.I definitely would not get the leather option, as I also think it looks tacky. I believe it's considered an "upgrade". The display is suppose to be superb on the G4. However, we'll see once it hits the streets. Honestly, I have no idea if I'll get one. I'm just curious to see how it stacks up, before locking in on an M9 or S6.
NOTE: I just saw this:http://www.gsmarena.com/lg_g4_allege...news-11937.php

I completely agree with you; putting speakers on the back is a poor choice.I definitely would not get the leather option, as I also think it looks tacky. I believe it's considered an "upgrade". The display is suppose to be superb on the G4. However, we'll see once it hits the streets. Honestly, I have no idea if I'll get one. I'm just curious to see how it stacks up, before locking in on an M9 or S6.
NOTE: I just saw this:http://www.gsmarena.com/lg_g4_allege...news-11937.php

Perhaps but the Z4 will probably have a bigger battery anyway. It also has much better speakers which are important to me since I watch a lot of youtube/podcasts on my phone. It will have a good shooter and a light skin.
I don't really like LG phones. The G4 isn't the prettiest looking thing and I'm not a fan of the leather.
LG will have a removable battery.The leather back is merely an option. It doesn't come with leather by default.
LG will have a removable battery.The leather back is merely an option. It doesn't come with leather by default.
ive said my peace about the s6..returned it too

What did you not like about the s6
Posted via the Android Central App

I checked out the S6 today. The only thing I liked about it was the display, and only in Samsung apps. Otherwise it seems to drag a bit more than the M9. Somehow the device felt hollow when I held it. It felt really cheap honestly. It really surprised me. I expected a depth to it. It wasn't there. I guess it felt too light for the materials maybe? I can't describe it. I think I wanted it to feel heavier. People say the iPhone feels like a toy, but it truly felt like a cheap plastic toy to me.

I initially thought that as well with the demo but after I purchased it I have found the materials quiet nice. One thing that really struck me was the clickiness of the buttons, it feels so great compared to the shallow flush buttons of the m7. But overall I'm struggling to adjust to the S6, yes its display and camera are unbelievable but touchwizz is laggy and stuttery, WiFi is super flaky, the back button is on the right (like WTF!) And at night you can't dim the capacitive buttons - you have to put it into power save mode to turn them off (again WTF!) I'm still keeping it and I will try work through the issues but its a fill in until the M10 comes along.
Posted via the Android Central App

I was considering the M9 and S6 when I upgraded my phone last week, and I thought the opposite of what you did about the weight. I thought the M9 was too heavy in my hand, while the S6 felt much lighter and more modern (albeit, more slippery with the glass front and back). The build quality of the S6 looked just as good as the M9. So, this just shows everyone has different tastes to what feels good to them with a smartphone.

My m9 is pretty good except for the camera. For a 20mp I'm shocked that the pictures come out so bad but I heard there was a update that should fix that. Fingers crossed because I am pass the month to exchange it. I'm gonna wait for the note 5 to show what it's made of before I upgrade next year.

Still and well there is another update on the way, to repair that and the camera is on par if not in some cases superior to the 's6 from what I am reading.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
Wow, if I was having all those issues, I'd take it back too! The battery drain for photos is amazingly high. I don't know why anybody, not just you, cares about low light camera performance though. They had a good low-light camera on their phones before, and basically everybody except for me and five other people told them they didn't want it. 
I don't think the heat is much of an issue, as it falls in line with other devices I've tested (I'm an engineer). The problem is that HTC did a good job in getting heat to transfer from the internals to the back where it could be dissipated. This is great for the internal components, but odd for the user experience because it will always feel warmer than other devices. If you ran an S6 hard so the internal processor reached 102 degrees (and it does), the back would feel cool because it's holding the heat inside due to glass being a thermal insulator, not a conductor. By the way, aluminium is good at thermal conductance due to the cubic grain structure. So if you did have an S6 (which I also like, by the way), and an M9 with the same internal temperatures, pretty much everybody would say the S6 feels cool and the M9 feels hot. The plus side is that the M9 sheds heat at an amazing rate. I don't have the exact results in front of me right now, but it's something like a 30 degree drop in 90 seconds with a 50 degree airflow over the back.

My m9 works fine better than iPhone and ditched my Sony Xperia z3 HTC is the best out there so quit sniffling

title: Help for an Android / HTC newbie - M9 vs E8 (sprint)

thread.text:
Hi Guys,
So as the topic suggests I'm moving on from my Blackberry (insert joke about being stuck in the past) and finally coming through to android.
HTC seems like the right choice, not too big and very positive reviews..
I was pretty dead set on the M9, until I started reading the SPRINT reviews. While the phone has high critical acclaim, it is torn apart by sprint reviews saying it has very poor battery life (super important to me), drops calls, turns on apps by itself ect.
The E8, on the other hand, has much higher reviews and seemingly more battery life? What do you guys reccomend? What have your experiences been with the M9 vs E8?
Things like slight camera improvement don't matter to me. More just the function and daily life of the phone.
Thank you!

replies.text: I honestly don't know much about the E8. I didn't even know it was available with Sprint compatible bands. I've read not just the M9, but a few recent phones having connectivity issues with Sprint.

thread.text: I still have my M7 with Sprint. I am always losing data connectivity. I have no problems with dropped calls. But the data issue is so bad that I just use my friend's Verizon phone if I need to look something up. Sprint network in the Dallas/Ft. Worth area is horrible.

title: HTC Aero????

thread.text: Let me start off by saying I love HTC. That being said, I bought the M9 on the premise that it was a flagship that would be ahead of all previous HTC's. I understand that there is a M9+, and im a bit irritated I didnt get that phone. But I read today there is another flagship in the works just after releasing the M9. This bothers me because I wanted a true HTC flagship for at least a year. Maybe im ranting, but if im stuck with a phone for 2 years I at least want it to be top of the line for a while.

How it this Aero phone released "just after releasing the M9". It won't be until November is my understanding. That is almost 6 months later which is an eternity in tech. This isn't the same as the M9+ which was released a few weeks later but not globally. You have a point there. This company is hemorrhaging money this year and you want them to wait until Spring 2016 to do something about it to stem the tide? That's not realistic.
I just feel a bit cheated. Im starting to agree with some that the M9 isnt as impressive as it could have been. But im coming from an M7, so maybe I need to relax.

replies.text: I had an M7 before, yes you need to relax. lol. There is always going to be something better coming along. Besides, I am much happier with this phone now than I was in April when I first got it and I don't even have 5.1 yet.

thread.text: The rumors surrounding this phone have me confused. I've read that it is an "intermediate" device which I'm guessing means mid-range. I've also read that it's gonna be quad HD with some kind of brand new camera tech. Those two seem to fight each other. All I know is if they release something that soon after the M9, and it blows it out of the water I won't be the only peeved customer. I'm not saying I don't like or am disappointed in the M9, because I'm not. I quite like. But $650 is a lot to spend to have a better device released only 6 months later by the same company. Guess we'll have to wait and see.

thread.text:
I think there are several reasons why it's a little quieter over here. The biggest is sales. There are just more S6/S6 Edge and G4 users than M9 users unfortunately. 
A second one is duplicate threads. There are at least 30 threads in the S6 forums related to battery life. I honestly think I'm downplaying the 30.
Also, I think there are more M9 users that are previous HTC owners. So a lot of the little things don't get threads because a good many users on this forum know about settings/optimizations already. 
I've noticed a quantity over quality on some of the other threads as well. There are tons of "I agree" or "Me too" posts on those threads. It's not a bad thing, but it adds to the total posts. I read most of the posts on here, but if I feel like my response isn't new or helpful in anyway I don't post. I've noticed other M9 users are the same. There are fewer "you're wrong", "X phone sucks", X phone is the best phone ever" here.
There seems to be a lot of opposing viewpoints on the Samsung threads in general, which in turn leads to more posts. 
Like it or not, the M9 didn't change as much as the other flagships this year. No new radical design, no new display tech, etc. So there are fewer questions regarding new tech.
Finally, with the exception of the M9 camera, there seems to be fewer problems overall than the other phones.
Really the one thread that bums me out is the "post your pics" thread, which I started so it only adds to the disappointment. It's more of a discussion than a place to post photos it seems. I'm at fault as much as others though because I haven't posted a ton of pics either. I unfortunately haven't had the time to get out and really put it to task. Hopefully that'll change though.

I guess I was just really surprised coming from bb at the low level of forum posts and participation...i thought it would be much much more. As a lot of posts are centred around problems, perhaps less posts mean less complaints with the device?

title: Not Sure if anyone;s run into this issue with GMAIL

thread.text:
For some reason I am not getting any notifications for incoming emails with the GMAIL app
I have an alternate Gmail address setup with mail app and i do receive notifications from that app letting me know I have new emails. 
Has anyone else had this issue?
I have gone through and made sure i have the sync settings activated

Make sure that in the GMail app info (through Application Manager) the Notifications aren't disabled for GMail or that you haven't set GMail as a non-priority notification on Lollipop.
If it persists, try logging out of the GMail app and logging back in.

Welcome to Android Central! Also, open Gmail, swipe in from the left and tap Settings, then select the account that's not notifying you. Make sure its notification settings are turned on appropriately, since you can turn off notifications for individual accounts.

title: Why do I have a Jittery screen after update?

thread.text:
So, i'm new to the world of custom ROMs. I have always used stock phones, but i wanted to check out these ROMs that people rave about. I read up on how to unlock bootloader, root, and install custom recovery/ROM. It all seemed pretty straight forward. The documentation online was good, all the steps worked fine. But i seem to have picked up some weird side effect that won't go away, and renders my phone nearly useless.
After installing Adroid Revolution HD, my screen is jittery and nearly unresponsive to touch unless the phone is plugged into a charging cable. I thought i must have done something wrong, so i wiped and reinstalled, same issue. I think okay, maybe it's just something with that build, so i downloaded and installed the most recent previous version. Still same issue. 
So i thought, ARHD is just crappy on my own HTC One M9 on AT&T. So i downloaded and installed Viper ROM, and have the same issue. What gives??
So next i go directly to HTC. The tech that helped me tells me this jiitery screen issue happens sometimes after an update, he's sure he can help me. Yay! He advised me to wipe my cache partition - no problem! So i did that and i still have the jittery screen issue. I can't use my phone unless it's plugged into a USB charging cable now. So pissed i didn't leave it stock!
So i'm humbly asking anyone out there for help. I can fall back on the Uh Oh protection, but seems like there must be an easy fix that i just don't know about.
So... thanks everyone.
Flashed back to stock HTC ROM. All is good now.

title: Wi-Fi Range

thread.text: Am I the only one experiencing this issue? I had an M8 and switched over to the M9 due to my camera sensor constantly buzzing not able to focus. The Wi-Fi range on my M9 isn't as strong as the M8. I was able to get on the internet and used internet-based apps with my previous phone while in bed but I can't with the new one. Is there anything I can do to get around this?

Are you sure this is a problem with your phone? I'm just wondering if it is more to do with the settings of your router.
Sent from my HTC One M9 using Tapatalk

My M9 is giving me the same coverage as my note 3 and my S6. I would have the WiFi tested at the shop. 
Sent from my 0PJA2 using Tapatalk

You may want to describe your setup for better help. Are you connected at 2.4GHz or 5.0GHz? What was your M8 connected at? While 5.0 is faster, it has a shorter range and is more susceptible to interference. Sometimes, repositioning the router or changing the channel on it can make a big difference.

My router has the option for a 2.4 and 5.0 connection. I changed the settings on my M9 to connect only to the 2.4 and the connection is weak and cuts out when I'm on my bed. I don't know what my M8 was connected to but it was at default settings.

How does it do in other rooms? If it is an issue throughout the house, I would make these attempts- forget and setup the connection on the phone again, reset the router, try a different channel on the router, hard reset the phone. If all fail to fix it, you face the possibility of a faulty phone.

It's fine in the other rooms. I'll face my door and I'll have connection. I'll do a 180 and have little to no connection. I'll try a different channel. I've reset the router and forget and setup the connection already. I'll try everything one more time. My last resort is to get a S6 which I really don't want to do
Turns out I had a faulty device. I exchanged it with a new one and everything is fine. Thanks everyone for the help!

replies.text:
Using our Consumer Testing Platform, we measured transfer speeds from the 32GB SanDisk Ultra Plus memory card, which gave us sequential speeds of 46.6MB/s read and 11.8MB/s write; the memory card came in above the claimed speeds. The EVO had speeds of 44.6MB/s read and 19.0MB/s write, which were right on par with the SanDisk Ultra Plus. It was slower than the retiring Samsung Plus, which had sequential speeds of 70.00MB/s read, while write activity hit 19.82MB/s.
Switching to random large-block transfers, we measured slower speeds at 43.03MB/s read and 3.87MB/s write. These were much lower than the Samsung cards on the write side; the EVO had 44.0MB/s read and an impressive 31.6MB/s write and the Samsung Plus had random large-block transfer speeds measured at 66.13MB/s read and 19.71MB/s write
It's about the SD version but it should be the same with MicroSD
The EVO is still the best for Write speed in this category of price.SanDisk Ultra Plus SD Memory Card Review (32GB) | StorageReview.com - Storage Reviews
I read that review as well. I've pretty much decided to go with the Lexar 633x I think. It's about $10 more, but should pull close to double the speed of the EVO. (Theoretically anyway.)

thread.text:
I've been using non-volatile storage (which is what an SD card is) since it first came out - as a 40 pin nitride IC - so I have a little bit of experience with the different manufacturers. (Actually, EPROMs came out even earlier, but they're not the same kind of technology, so I'm trying to compare at least fruit with fruit, not with cars.) And I've always bought only SanDisk. In a few decades, the only "bad" card I've ever had was a microSD card that I cracked in half (and klutziness isn't covered by the warranty). My 256MB (not GB - MB) card still works LONG after the warranty ran out.
When Samsung messed up the 4.3 update and it started eating cards, who came out with the fix? Not Samsung - SanDisk modified their cards to work with the bad update.
You want at least a U1 (Class 10 - same thing in a different numbering system) card, but if you're planning on recording 4k video you want a U3 card (U1 isn't fast enough for 4k). There's no "Class 30" card - cards are now rated by the U number.
Remember also - the speeds the cards are rated at are burst speeds - you can write a sector really fast, but if you try to write 2GB at once, it's going to be a lot slower. (It's like putting letters into pigeon holes - it may take 1 second to put one in, but getting the next letter, reading it, scanning for the correct pigeon hole and putting the letter in it takes longer. Not a perfect analogy, but something like that.) As long as the card is truly rated - and Samsung and SanDisk cards are - a U3 card is fast enough for 4k video. (I prefer dealing with SanDisk - I've had the pleasure of having had to, and considering how some companies make you jump through hoops just to get to a real person, dealing with SanDisk is a pleasure.)
Whatever you buy, install SD Insight and run it when the card is in the phone. If you see the card was made in 1970, or it's a 4GB card, you have a counterfeit card. They can duplicate the packaging and the printing on the card so even a microscope can't tell it from the real thing - but when SD Insight sees a 4GB memory chip inside the card, it's all over. (And a lot of counterfieters leave the date set to 0, which is Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 GMT. They didn't make microSD cards in 1970.)

title: Trouble Streaming music to the car.

thread.text: I'm having trouble streaming music/media from my M9 5.0.2 to the car via Bluetooth. I can connect and use the phone just fine. The "media player" will only connect for 2-3 seconds and then drop the connection. I've tried to unpair and pair. I've tried deleting the phone from the car system and reconnecting. I've tried connecting using HTC Connect to pair. I've deleted the Bluetooth app cache and data then restarted the phone. I even disconnected the battery on my car reseting all the cars' data. I've tried all these things in multiple combinations and multiple times. Same result, drops the connection after 2-3 seconds. My previous phone (HTC DNA) had no issues connecting and streaming music. Pretty frustrating. Any help, thoughts or suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.
Welcome to Android Central! Are there any other Bluetooth devices in the car that might be competing? Like a Bluetooth headset?

Thank you. Glad to be here. 
No, no other devices in the car.
Could the "phone" be with competing with the "media player" some way, some how? Some sort of software bug?

replies.text: No, it shouldn't be. Bluetooth has separate profiles for Phone Audio and Media Audio.

thread.text: What car? Year make model and trim level.
2013 Toyota Sienna XLE

replies.text:
No idea if Toyota is like Ford, but you need to update your car to work with the latest bluetooth version.
Posted via Android Central App
How do I update my Toyota car software?

thread.text:
Check your owners manual... With Ford, you use a thumb drive
Posted via Android Central App

Had some time today and got this sorted out. I cleared all Bluetooth settings on the phone. Disconnected the car battery for 10 min. Connected the battery. Set all car Bluetooth settings to "default" and another tab that said "register device". Used HTC Connect to pair. It paired right away, and is not dropping the connection. working like a charm now!
Thanks for all your help and suggestions

Glad it worked for you. Sounds like a master reset
Posted via the Android Central App
I had this same issue, since I bought my car second hand and it had a bunch of devices in the list. After I cleared it, it worked fine.

I had the same problem with my Honda. I paired my phone just fine, but then it would repeatedly connect and disconnect. I finally figured out a solution, though not ideal. In the Bluetooth connection for the Honda HandsFreeLink on your phone, uncheck the box that gives Honda access to contacts and messages. This leaves phone and media checked. My phone now stays connected all the time. 
I'm not technical, but I'm guessing that there is some sort of electronic hand shake that is not happening properly when the car is trying to connect to the other services. That causes the phone to power off and back on its Bluetooth radio and thus cause the continuous disconnect/connect cycles.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: Why is the HTC M9 taking 9hrs to charge,even with QuickCharger2.0?

thread.text:
The Htc M9 was charging perfectly till about a week ago,since then it says '9hrs until full' Even from 30% even with QuickCharger 2.0. Please Help,its really bothering me,I got the phone a month ago,battery shouldnt be out so soon,
could this be after the update a few days ago? PLEASE HELP!!
No way it should take that long. I would get a replacement.

Welcome to Android Central! When it's charging from a wall outlet, does it say "Charging (AC)" or "Charging (USB)"? If it says USB, then the charging plug, the cable, or the microUSB port might be the issue. Make sure the microUSB port is clear of any debris. Try using a different cable. If neither works, then replace the charger. If the replacement charger doesn't work, then there's probably something wrong with the microUSB port.

Did you update to the 1.40 version? There is a bug that causes slow charging on some devices. Apparently this doesn't affect everybody. Have a look here: http://forums.androidcentral.com/htc...ce-update.html
Try recalibrating the battery. It worked for some of us.
If that doesn't work, then before charging your device, reboot it and plug it in. It should work at least once..
The new 2.7 firmware (currently in beta testing by HTC) solves this issue..
If you're trying to charge by usb, it will take forever.
The OP said in his original post that he is using the Rapid Charger 2.0, so how could he be charging via USB?

title: New to Android/M9 - Recommended Apps?

thread.text:
I've been an Apple user for years. Only for my phone though. And they've always been jailbroken, since I created my own tweaks. I did marketing for Google for a little in 2012 and they gave me a Nexus 4 but I gave it to my dad so I don't have much experience with Android. Recommended apps for newish Android users? Any category.
Posted via the Android Central App
Nova Launcher, Renotify, Todo-ist, Sync for Reddit (if you go on Reddit), Clarity Keyboard, and Shuttle+ (for local music playing)

i use these apps on my phone
mx player for videos, it provides some good functions you'll know once you start using it
fast notepad saves your notes in .txt format so you don't have to sync your phone for any backups just drag and drop the folder 
with notes in your pc
zarchiver - can unpack probably any archived file
avast mobile security
avast grimefighter - it helps getting rid of cache and other unwanted files

If you are also using Macs, then I suggest the following:Play Music Manager to sync your iTunes library to the Google Cloud servicesPushbullet. It provides handoff similar integration with your Mac. You can send and receive SMS on your Mac and it also allows you to receive notifications.If you are using Exchange for Mail, then buy Nine. The best app available.Use DropBox as a way to send files to your Mac / keep them in sync1Password as a Password ManagerWunderlist for tasks. Multiplatform and it works very wellTalon as a Twitter client. It is similar in quality to Tweetbot for iOS.OneNote or Evernote for notes

Coming from IOS and you still want to use your contacts and calender from iCloud account and be able to sync to your desktop Outlook Calender. The best way to do that is:
1.) Smoothsync for Calender
2.) Smoothsync for Contacts
Other than that. I wouldn't bother with an Antivirus at this point. Lollipop checks apps you install and unless you are installing APK's from unknown sources and you don't know if they are shady, you should be staying away from them anyway. It just commands resources and slows your phone down and can be a battery drainer as well.
Other apps I would include that aren't mentioned.
1.) GSAM - Monitors battery usage
2.) Genius Scan - scans images you can upload to pretty much any cloud storage
3.) Zedge - for custom tones and ringtones
4.) Photo Express - to edit and open RAW files
5.) Pocket Cast - for podcasts

title: Best way to keep your htc clean ie files, data etc

thread.text:
Dont really know how to go about doing this without messing up the phone itself. 
Clear instructions please if you can 
Thanks
Posted via the Android Central App

Welcome to Android Central! To be honest, I wouldn't worry too much about it. "Junk cleaner" apps might be more trouble than they're worth, since they often claim to be "memory booster" apps as well, and do things that are counterproductive to how Android is designed to work. Other kinds of junk cleaners might actually do things you don't want, like automatically uninstall apps you haven't used in a month or so (without warning you).
It's true that sometimes apps may leave behind some data directories after uninstallation. I periodically look through the directories using a file manager app and delete any directory that clearly belongs to an uninstalled app. But this often doesn't account for much storage anyway.
Clearing app caches can be done without a 3rd party app--just go to Settings>Storage, tap Cached Data, then agree to clear the caches. For the most part, though, there's no need to do this if the phone is otherwise working normally.

Ok here a daylight comparison between the old (actual European Rom) and the new 1.40 With the old HTC Camera M9:Crop Old HTC Camera M9With the new HTC Camera M9Crop New HTC Camera M9And the S6 Crop:
As you can see the color reproduction is now Amazing with the Jpeg of the HTC M9, even better than on S6, details also are much better .

The problem with this as I stated in the XDA thread is we don't have a DSLR camera reference for what the actual colour of the building is. Second, I still haven't seen any pictures with respect to improvement in low light processing. Third, they don't have OIS but they do have EIS and so does the iPhone 6 so it is possible through software to improve the video "Blairwitching" that occurs. I don't think HTC is up to that task though. That said, I look forward to any improvements coming.

replies.text: I will take a photo with my Nikon D90 DSLR tomorrow of the same place but I can assure you than my human eyes said the M9 with 1.40 FW has better colors now

Why is their a problem? The improvement is obvious. Whatever the natural color of the building, it appears to be the same color with both phones now, the S6 just has more brightness. This will be two updates since release that greatly improve the camera. The majority of consumers should be satisfied with this update, but that doesn't mean there won't be further improvements after this update. And the majority of those that still aren't satisfied or still want to complain probably don't even have the phone. Like you, I would like to see some low light shots and will take any improvement over nothing.

At this point, it is only the lack of OIS in the video taking that I find unacceptable. I can live with everything else about the camera to be honest, even more so after this update. 
We must be looking at different pictures. That building is different colours on all three cameras. It is darker on the old M9, lighter on the new M9 and flat out washed out on the S6. What is the actual shade I should have asked more specifically.
Posted via the Android Central App

This is never mentioned when comparing photos. How can we possibly know the ability to recreate an image of we cant see the original. All comparisons never mention this and just say out of the pics shown this one did it the best see.
I remember up until a few years ago when reviewers did smartphone camera shootouts, at least a decent point and shoot was used for reference. Recently though, reviewers don't seem to bother.

thread.text: When you refer to "new camera" are you talking about version 4.0 that added raw capture or is there something else I'm not aware of?

replies.text: There is another update coming. The above samples are from that update.
The firmware version right now starts 1.32.XXXX. The new one is 1.40.XXXX.

Oh, ok. So the update will be incorporated into the next incremental OS update rather than an update of the camera app itself in the Playstore if I read your reply correct. I was wondering why they just couldn't update the camera app and post it for download from the Playstore, but I guess it's more complicated than that.

Not exactly, the next OS is Android Lollipop 5.1.1 and we won't be getting that for a few months. This is just an OTA from HTC updated the firmware to a new version of it which we should have in a few weeks. It includes improvements to Sense in terms of performance and battery life as well as post processing changes to the images the camera produces. This is not to be confused with the HTC Camera app in the Play Store which is more about new features and bug fixes within the app itself.

thread.text: Here a photo taken with my Nikon D90 DSLR

replies.text: Based on the DSLR image. The new HTC firmware actually doesn't match the colours of the building. I downloaded M9 and S6 close ups and viewed the images side by side on my desktop with the DSLR image. The HTC close up is darker than it should be. The S6 close up is more washed out and is too light compared to the DSLR sample. The 1.40 is an improvement overall though.
You know which one looks better right? Big improvement. You should be thrilled, yet you seem hell bent on ragging on the M9. I can't believe you are still hanging on to it.

Thrilled? C'mon... take of your HTC pajamas. If you actually read what I wrote I said neither camera actually captured the colour of the actual building , one is too light and one is too dark, but that the new HTC firmware is an improvement overall from previous firmware. I am not on here to defend HTC 24/7 which appears to be your full time job. I just call it like I see it. I bought the phone so I am not on here trolling like some other peeps who don't have it and never intent to by it. So I am entitled to my opinion.

Okay based on the DSLR image, can we agree that the new update for the HTC One m9 puts it on par with the S6 camera ?
Posted via the Android Central App

Ummm, no. Because as I've said. My issue has never been photos in great lighting but low light ones and the shaky video. There are no details on those improvements.
Posted via the Android Central App

You can't get the same results as on the S6 with M9 for very low light, take it for granted!
The S6 has an OIS that helps reduce the shutter speed up to 1/8s while with the M9 it's perhaps about 1/20s, slower than that and the photo is blurred, so yes the S6 has naturally more light coming in the low light photos that why the S6 doesn't need to use ISO 1600 that produces lot of noise to compensate like the M9 does.
I am like many others a daylight photo shooter, I rarely take photos at night so I don't bother.
Btw I took selfies with the S6 in low light and the results were catastrophic while the M9 was crisp and detailed.
If you are so in need to take low light photos and you take loooot of them (and not selfies) then get the S6.
This thread was made to show how great the camera is now on M9 for daylight

thread.text: I am no photography expert, but to my eyes and at least in bright sunlight it looks good. The question is, how does the camera perform in low light situations? What about video recording?
Look at the difference between the iPhone 6 and the iPhone 6 Plus. You can barely see it, despite the fact that the iPhone 6 has no OIS.

replies.text:
In low light or very low light?
The M9 can take good photos in low light using the manual controls but in very low light it will use a high ISO of 1600 that will make noise, though if you resize to facebook size (1 to 4MP) you will get very nice photos whatever the condition.
I daylight you can crop at 100% while keeping high details specially with RAW

thread.text:
During daylight, shooting at low iso, most cameras perform similarly... the dynamic range and sharpness are optimal in these conditions and it takes pixel peeping to try to distinguish the difference between sensors... 
Also, it's not a fair comparison anyways when you have two different sensors at different resolutions and you take 100% crops... one is bound to not look equal to the other when they are "zoomed in" and compared
I'm thinking about the m9 and I'm wandering if this would be a worthy upgrade over the m7. 98% of the time I take pictures in bright daylight and some videos

replies.text: Yes in daylight you can take superb photos and 1080p to 4K videos, better get a large SD card
Do you have the recommended settings to take "superb" pics? Also do you have any recommendations for a large sd card @ a good price?

It's recommended to lower the sharpness to -1, some people even lower it to -1.5.
If you plan to save your photos and videos directly to your SDcard then a fast one is recommended like a Sandisk Extreme, Samsung Pro or PNY Turbo, though if you plan to save directly to internal memory then backup on SD you can choose whatever card you want

Does it have really better display brightness for outdoor viewing than the m7. I view/take pictures/video outside in bright sunlight but this is almost impossible to accomplish on the m7. What other features are better on the m9 vs m7 (battery life,etc...)?

The sunlight visibility is better yes, the M9 has a sort of new polarized layer on the screen giving better results while keeping the colors very natural.
You will love the camera, UI with themes, speakers (they are better than M7), speed, the new metallic colors...

I had the M7 before and have the M9 now. The M9 is better outdoors for viewing. You just have to remember to turn off auto brightness because it is way to aggressive. At full brightness you will have no issues. Even at 2 bars brightness you will be ok outside on an overcast day. Battery life is better, it is way faster, It is way louder, the camera is way better, in general it is just superior. Button placement is better as well, plus you now have an SD card slot. I prefer the on screen buttons and use the 4th button more than I thought I would. You will also like having tap to wake and other gestures.
Just out of curiosity, what do you have your 4th button set up for?

Power.
Posted via the Android Central App
I initially had mine set up for quick settings/notifications, but now I've got it set to hide the on screen buttons. I don't use it all that often though.
You finally bought the M9?
Where have you been? I've had it since April.

Sprint loyalty discount for the M9 through the end of June is $5 per month lease for 2 years, or $120. Can buy the phone for $200 more after that or turn it in. He is going to Russia for semester abroad and Sprint also has unlimited 2G data for free in Russia and free messaging and phone calls to and from the USA to Russia, and free Wifi calling to USA. replies.text: With AT&T, a two year contract costs $600 on my plan. Plus $99 would be $699, so that wouldn't even be a deal for me. With my plan, if you bring your own device, buy the phone outright, or finance the phone, you get a monthly discount of $25. If you take the discounted phone with the two year contract, you lose the monthly discount. That is where I get the $600 figure, 25 x 24 = 600.

title: My HTC ONE started to expect voice commands where keyboard input is required, why?

thread.text:
without me doing anything, my (new) HTC ONE M9 started requiring me to SPEAK the necessary text (e.g. passwords) instead of presenting the keyboard where one would normally type the text.
Started with VIBER OUT (when I tried to purchase credit) but now it is pervasive - AY text input is expected through voice.

replies.text:
Welcome to Android Central!
Try looking in the accessibility menu and see if you have the Vision impaired option turned on.

title: Another thread about upgrading to HTC M9 from an older HTC device

thread.text:
Hey guys,
How are you all on this fine Saturday?
Yes, here you have it. Another thread asking whether upgrading to the latest device is worthwhile.
Here is the twist though, I am currently cruising on the HTC One M7.
How did I hold onto a phone for 2 years? *gasps and shock fill the room*.
To be honest it was easy. With the front facing speakers, Sense UI which just makes sense and a nice 4.7 form factor it was easy and still is.
However, for the last 3 months my camera has come down with the purple hue disease. A camera is not the most important feature of a smartphone to me but it is up there in the top 10.
If it wasn't for this purple hue, I would not be looking at a new phone at all as it still runs like the first day out of the box *hugs sense* with no lag in the UI.
There are just a few things I would like to know from other HTC enthusiasts before considering the M9.
1. Are the issues with the Snapdragon 810 over heating is true?
2. Are the front facing speakers still as loud and crisp as the M7?
3. Do you see any stutter or lag in the Sense UI?
4. Other than themes, has Sense really seen that much more of an improvement over 2 years?
5. Handling a 4.7 inch form factor phone and going to a 5 inch is it really that much bigger?
If anyone can enlighten me, I would be truly thankful.
In the end, I am really just wondering if I can hold of on the M9 and just wait for the M10. By that time the snap dragon processors should be blitzing again and the devices wont be running that troublesome lollipop version.

I came from where you are so I understand the question. I also think it's funny that like me your purple issue developed late in the life of your M7. If what everyone was complaining about was what I was seeing I have to ask myself how was there any question about could this be normal like I was seeing early on in the discussions. Anyway to your questions...
1. I have noticed the phone getting a little hot. Once I was running an app that required some to complete and found that not only did the phone heat up but it stopped taking a charge. Once I unplugged it and allowed it to cool down it seemed fine but that was kind of scary. So far it hasn't appeared to be anything device threatening, but you may want to wait for other opinions on that.
2. Actually they are slightly louder, but still not pre speaker blown scare loud like the M7 had been. Personally I would just go into a store and compare them side by side, because you'll want to put your hands on one before committing anyway.
3. No lag at all. It is so much smoother and faster than the M7, which I never noticed any issue with when I owned it, but going back now OMG, there is such a difference.
4. I would have to say not really. You will probably notice some of the changes, but most of the changes are similar to the ones you probably got recently with the Sense update. Honestly between the two, the Sense update for the M7 and the Sense version that came on the device I haven't noticed much. Maybe a few more themes for the updated version, or at least not the warning that a theme may not perform as well on an older version.
5. Again you are going to want to put one in your hand for this. For me I barely notice any difference, that could be because the M9 is thinner, I have big hands anyway, any number of things, but it really didn't seem to be much of an issue for me. What I noticed more than the size change was the weight change. The M9 is so much lighter. I barely know i have it in my pocket. I keep checking that I have it.
GL

I never had the M7. But the M9 has been absolutely fantastic. Having owned the S6 and G4 the M9 has been the best of the group for me. So much so I was shocked myself. 
I have had the phone for a couple of weeks now and I am very impressed. Everytime I use it I am shocked and how fluid this device is. 
In regard to girl cAmera both the G4 and S6 are much better but for the the M9 serves my needs. 
Speed on the device HD excellent. No lag for me. Everything is super smooth especiAlly when typing which both previous phones had issues with. 
Battery has been good for me as well. It lasts me the day with moderate use. So no issues there. It's not a battery that will last you for days but for moderate use it should last you all day no problems. 
Best of luck on your decisions. This has been the best phone I have owned so far. I would go with others have stated and try one in store and get a feel for it on your own. 
Sent from my HTC6535LVW using Tapatalk
